column2: Lily, when she had once accepted Crosbie, seemed to think that she could never be too near to him.

column2: She had been in no wise ashamed of her love, and had shown it constantly by some little caressing motion of her hand, leaning on his arm, looking into his face, as though she were continually desirous of some palpable assurance of his presence.
column3: She had been in no wise ashamed of her love, and had shown it constantly by some little caressing motion of her hand, leaning on his arm, looking into his face, as though she were continually desirous of some palpable assurance of his presence.

column2: It was not so at all with Bell.
column3: It was not so at all with Bell.

column2: She was happy in loving and in being loved, but she required no overt testimonies of affection.
column3: She was happy in loving and in being loved, but she required no overt testimonies of affection.

column2: I do not think it would have made her unhappy if some sudden need had required that Crofts should go to India and back before they were married.
column3: I do not think it would have made her unhappy if some sudden need had required that Crofts should go to India and back before they were married.

column2: The thing was settled, and that was enough for her.
column3: The thing was settled, and that was enough for her.

column2: But, on the other hand, when he spoke of the expediency of an immediate marriage, she raised no difficulty.
column3: But, on the other hand, when he spoke of the expediency of an immediate marriage, she raised no difficulty.

column2: As her mother was about to go into a new residence, it might be as well that that residence should be fitted to the wants of two persons instead of three.
column3: As her mother was about to go into a new residence, it might be as well that that residence should be fitted to the wants of two persons instead of three.

column2: So they talked about chairs and tables, carpets and kitchens, in a most unromantic, homely, useful manner! A considerable portion of the furniture in the house they were now about to leave belonged to the squire,--or to the house rather, as they were in the habit of saying.
column3: So they talked about chairs and tables, carpets and kitchens, in a most unromantic, homely, useful manner! A considerable portion of the furniture in the house they were now about to leave belonged to the squire,--or to the house rather, as they were in the habit of saying.

column2: The older and more solid things,--articles of household stuff that stand the wear of half a century,--had been in the Small House when they came to it.
column3: The older and more solid things,--articles of household stuff that stand the wear of half a century,--had been in the Small House when they came to it.

column2: There was, therefore, a question of buying new furniture for a house in Guestwick,--a question not devoid of importance to the possessor of so moderate an income as that owned by Mrs. Dale.
column3: There was, therefore, a question of buying new furniture for a house in Guestwick,--a question not devoid of importance to the possessor of so moderate an income as that owned by mrs Dale.

column2: In the first month or two they were to live in lodgings, and their goods were to be stored in some friendly warehouse.
column3: In the first month or two they were to live in lodgings, and their goods were to be stored in some friendly warehouse.

column2: Under such circumstances would it not be well that Bell's marriage should be so arranged that the lodging question might not be in any degree complicated by her necessities?
column3: Under such circumstances would it not be well that Bell's marriage should be so arranged that the lodging question might not be in any degree complicated by her necessities?

column2: This was the last suggestion made by Dr. Crofts, induced no doubt by the great encouragement he had received.
column3: This was the last suggestion made by dr Crofts, induced no doubt by the great encouragement he had received.

column2: That would be hardly possible, said Mrs. Dale.
column3: That would be hardly possible, said mrs Dale.

column2: It only wants three weeks;--and with the house in such a condition!
column3: It only wants three weeks;--and with the house in such a condition!

column2: James is joking, said Bell.
column3: james is joking, said Bell.

column2: I was not joking at all, said the doctor.
column3: I was not joking at all, said the doctor.

column2: Why not send for Mr. Boyce, and carry her off at once on a pillion behind you? said Lily.
column3: Why not send for mr Boyce, and carry her off at once on a pillion behind you? said Lily.

column2: It's just the sort of thing for primitive people to do, like you and Bell.	It's just the sort of thing for primitive people to do, like you and Bell.
column3: true

column2: All the same, Bell, I do wish you could have been married from this house."
column3: All the same, Bell, I do wish you could have been married from this house."

column2: I don't think it will make much difference, said Bell.
column3: I don't think it will make much difference, said Bell.

column2: Only if you would have waited till summer we would have had such a nice party on the lawn.	Only if you would have waited till summer we would have had such a nice party on the lawn.
column3: true

column2: It sounds so ugly, being married from lodgings; doesn't it, mamma?"
column3: It sounds so ugly, being married from lodgings; doesn't it, mamma?"

column2: It doesn't sound at all ugly to me, said Bell.
column3: It doesn't sound at all ugly to me, said Bell.

column2: I shall always call you Dame Commonplace when you're married, said Lily.
column3: I shall always call you Dame Commonplace when you're married, said Lily.

column2: Then they had tea, and after tea Dr. Crofts got on his horse and rode back to Guestwick.
column3: Then they had tea, and after tea dr Crofts got on his horse and rode back to Guestwick.

column2: Now may I talk about him? said Lily, as soon as the door was closed behind his back.
column3: Now may I talk about him? said Lily, as soon as the door was closed behind his back.

column2: No; you may not.
column3: No; you may not.

column2: As if I hadn't known it all along!	As if I hadn't known it all along!
column3: true

column2: And wasn't it hard to bear that you should have scolded me with such pertinacious austerity, and that I wasn't to say a word in answer!"
column3: And wasn't it hard to bear that you should have scolded me with such pertinacious austerity, and that I wasn't to say a word in answer!"

column2: I don't remember the austerity, said Mrs. Dale.
column3: I don't remember the austerity, said mrs Dale.

column2: Nor yet Lily's silence, said Bell.
column3: Nor yet Lily's silence, said Bell.

column2: But it's all settled now, said Lily, "and I'm downright happy.
column3: But it's all settled now, said Lily, "and I'm downright happy.

column2: I never felt more satisfaction,--never, Bell!"
column3: I never felt more satisfaction,--never, Bell!"

column2: Nor did I, said her mother; "I may truly say that I thank God for this good thing."
column3: Nor did I, said her mother; "I may truly say that I thank God for this good thing."
